awd_titl_txt: An Analysis of the Integration of Place Attachment into Visualizations of Hurricane Storm Surge Threats
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates ways of reducing the devastating effects that hurricane related storm surges can have on the safety and well-being of communities. Reducing and managing risks from storm surge are challenging because of the complex nature of the hazard and the inherent uncertainty in storm surge forecasting. Weather forecasters and emergency managers often use maps and animations (visualizations) to communicate storm surge risks and threats to the public. However, little is known about how these visualizations influence people's understanding and response to risk. This project will contribute to research on visualizations and how well these work for the communication of hazardous weather risks.  By focusing on attachment to place within the context of coastal communities, the investigators will improve understanding of how people interact with information about coastal hazards and what role visualizations play in understanding and decision-making. The investigators will engage with practitioners and stakeholders throughout the project, from the planning stages to dissemination of the research results, ensuring project relevancy and building strong societal benefit for the needs of affected communities. This project will support educational activities through interdisciplinary training of students and faculty at a variety of institutions including from minority serving colleges and universities. The project will contribute to broader efforts to increase public scientific literacy by focusing on the role of visualizations in communicating complex scientific concepts in a relatable and usable manner. 

This project will contribute to fundamental theoretical and methodological advances in geography, geospatial science, cartography, as well as decision, risk and management science and their intersection with communication of hazardous weather risks.  The research will bridge the gap between how spatially explicit storm surge information is being conveyed by scientists and their interpretation and use by members of the public in at-risk coastal communities. The investigators will consider the role of concepts such as space and place in data representation and hypothesize that connecting people to place through theoretically and empirically informed visualizations will enhance at-risk populations' understandings of and responses to storm surge hazard threats.  The project's research questions are: How do residents of coastal communities perceive a sense of place in their everyday lives and when hazardous storm surge threatens? How can sense of place constructs be integrated into visualization of storm surge threats? How do different ways of representing space and place in storm surge visualizations interact with people's understandings of and responses to the hazards? The investigators will use a multi-method interdisciplinary approach that employs an experimental participatory cognitive mapping process, research on and development of innovative storm surge visualizations, iterative focus groups on risk perception and the degree to which attachment to place factors in to decision-making, and an online survey to test the impact of different types of visualizations.  Together this suite of methods will be able to inform how the visualizations, attachment to place, and other factors influence people's understandings of and responses to storm surge hazards.  The research includes stakeholder engagement in coastal areas and experts from several related government agencies. Although the project focuses on coastal Georgia and South Carolina, the methods, technology, and visualization concepts will be relevant to other coastal communities in the U.S. vulnerable to hurricane storm surge. Furthermore, the theories and empirical findings will be relevant to non-coastal communities by understanding how attachment to place within visualizations can be used to improve communication of risk hazards and decision-making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Weather forecasters and emergency managers use maps and other types of visualizations to communicate storm surge risks and threats to the public. The main goal of this project was to understand how visualizations enable coastal residents to understand and respond to risk. To do so, we explored the following research questions: 1) How do residents of coastal communities perceive a sense of place in their lives? 2) How can sense of place constructs be integrated into visualizations of storm surge risk? 3) How do different ways of representing space and place in storm surge visualizations interact with people's understanding of and responses to the storm surge risk information? 

We used an interdisciplinary approach to create new knowledge about a sense of place, effectiveness of geovisualizations, and visual risk communication. First, we empirically explored the concepts of place meaning, scale of place, and place attachment in the context of coastal communities at risk to hurricane storm surge, using an experimental participatory cognitive mapping process. Second, we identified and implemented cartographic and visual design approaches for visualizing places affected by a storm surge flooding. Third, we conceptualized how visualizations may facilitate connection to a place, and thus increase personal relevance of information and developed measures of connecting to a place through visuals. Fourth, we developed six visualizations incorporating aspects of place meaning, scale of place, dimensionality and realism. Finally, we integrated the concepts, visualizations, and developed measures to assess the effectiveness of visualizations in a large online population survey. 

Key findings included the following: All six visualizations were generally effective in enabling people to connect to the place shown in the visuals. Our statistical analysis suggests that one visualization that combined a map of a coastal area with an inset map showing a three-dimensional scene of a neighborhood with simple shapes of buildings and streets names was the most helpful in enabling people to relate to a place shown in the visualization, quickly make sense of the information, and understand the risk. 

We found that place attachment played a significant role in how participants' perceived visual information and storm surge risk, and their intended protective behaviors during a hurricane threat. Place attachment among our study participants was generally high. Specifically, older participants and those with income greater than $100,000, longer lengths of residence in a community, and more years of formal education tended to have higher place attachment. Those with greater place attachment reported greater ability to relate to the information presented in the visualizations, envision themselves in the place shown on the map, quickly make sense of the information, and understand risks associated with storm surge using the information in the visual. People who were more place-attached also perceived greater risk from an approaching hurricane and said they were more likely to take protective actions compared to the people who were less place-attached. 

Our results show that while the visualizations of storm surge risk developed in this project can be effective generally, they appear to be less effective in several important and vulnerable groups. Overall, we saw substantial impacts of race, income, map reading ability, and place attachment on how people connected the risk shown in the visual to place. This may have potential downstream effects on subsequent risk perceptions and protective behaviors  and may indicate the potential for more systemic issues in participants' responses to risk information. These findings have implications for considering the way scientists communicate storm surge and other types of hazard information with diverse audiences through maps and other forms of geovisualizations. 

The project supported educational activities, through university classroom lessons and interdisciplinary training of students from a variety of institutions including from minority serving colleges and universities. We broadly shared the project's results with coastal practitioners, including emergency managers. The project contributed to broader efforts to increase public awareness of storm surge risks and threats by informing the Georgia Flood Literacy Project, an initiative of the Georgia Coastal Management Program that strove to increase consistency of flood-related terminology in public messaging by members of emergency management, academia, non-governmental organizations, state agencies, federal agencies, and local governments.
